text: smashed every club leader up until I got to the psychic club leader, who has an actual strategy and deck built around alakazam. I thought all hope was lost until I noticed alakazam couldn't actually do any damage to my lickitung. He uses gust of wind to blow out my other four mons, smashes them leaving me with only a lickitung and 40 turns to burn. I only won because I stalled him out of a deck. It's moments like that that make you really appreciate a particular pokemon. From now on I'll always have a soft spot for lickitung.
author: Boss

text: I always though the Club Master Duel soundtrack was far better than the Grand Master Duel soundtrack, which sounds goofy and comedic in comparison. This excellent piece has a strong and driving baseline, an ominous use of deep notes, and a flowing epic melody, which fits the final boss as much as the Club Masters.

author: BloodmakerLP

text:
+BloodmakerLP Deck of as many Level 35 Articunos as you can + loads of Water Energy, Potions, Super Potions, Energy Removals and Super Energy Removals = Game practically beaten.

Except on Murray, his Mr. Mime card negated all damage over 20. Using a deck of Rattata and Raticate will suffice. He often uses cards that seep on his remaining deck and doesn't prioritise Energising Kangaskhan; instead uses it to seep further into his deck, so it's an easy but lengthy win. He never uses his Chansey to attack, instead uses it as a meatshield, and the rest are Psychic which Rattata and Raticate are resistant to.

text: 8-bit music at it's finest.
author: Palider

text: I believe the GameBoy was 4-Bit.
author: lame gag

text: It's 8-bit. For example, each note takes two bits: One for the Control Volt (Which controls the pitch), and one for the Gate (which controls whether or not you hear the note).
author: Vexnos 0zymandias

text:
+DJ 0zymandias Correct me if I'm wrong. As far as I know people regard to this music as "8-bit" because the processor of the NES was 8-bit, and therefore everything NES/Gameboy related (graphics, music, etc.) is globally regarded as "8-bit", while the actual bit depth of the sound is 4-bits. That is, the voltage can only be found at one of 16 discrete steps at a given moment in time (0000, 0001, 0010, 0011, 0100, 0101...)

Also how can a single bit control the pitch if a bit can only have one of two values, 0 or 1?
author: Koori Graywolf

text: CV/gate (an abbreviation of control voltage/gate) is an analog method of controlling synthesizers, drum machines and other similar equipment with external sequencers. The control voltage typically controls pitch and the gate signal controls note on-off. Two different signals for one note. hence the restriction to four sounds. Only eight signals could be sent at once.
author: Vexnos 0zymandias

text: Ok ok, but if the control voltage is an analog how can it have a bit assigned to it?
author: Koori Graywolf

text: The CV would be digitally controlled. The controller has the bit assigned to it, and adjusts the CV and Gate accordingly.
author: Vexnos 0zymandias

text: What I don't understand is how a single bit can control a voltage range. A bit can only have a value of either 1 or 0, that is, on or off. In order to control a range, you'd need various bits in order to have a range (1 bit for a range of 2 steps, 2 bits for a range of 4 steps, 3 bits for a range of 8 steps, etc.). If it was a BYTE, then I'd understand how it can control a voltage level, that would be 256 discrete steps. But then that'd be 8 bits for a single channel.
author: Koori Graywolf

text: Well, a lot of random number generators in programming aren't technically random but instead use a large list of different numbers that the game scrolls through. So, when a save state is used, it is still in the same spot in that list of numbers and the coin seems predetermined.
author: sephirothsdemise

text: lol that is terrible...Why even have a coin flip if you are going to predetermine every value before the flip even occurs? Seems stupidly pointless.

text:
I never really enjoyed Pokemon as much as most other people do (I do like it, but it's not the best thing in the world or anything) but I really enjoyed every second I played  this game. The only problem I had with it is that it was way too easy, because you could just swap into an opposite element and kick the heck out of your enemies. Also, the "psychic" class was way too strong, as it hardly had any weaknesses.

Other than that, great game!
